channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Surge in Executions Worries Rights Experts
item.description: Iran reportedly hanged 40 people in the first two weeks of January, 33 of them in the last week, leading United Nations human rights experts to call for a halt to the executions.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: More Police Are Fired or Reassigned
item.description: Nearly 500 police officers were either fired or reassigned Wednesday in what appears to be a purge related to a graft inquiry that has already ensnared many of the prime minister’s allies.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Businesses Seized in Inquiry Tied to Mob Boss
item.description: An investigation linked to a Neapolitan mob boss led to the seizure of 27 pizzerias, cafes and other restaurants in the heart of Rome as well as other businesses elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: New Push Is Made to Free an American While Iran Is at the Negotiating Table
item.description: Advocates argue that a diplomatic window created by the nuclear deal is a new opportunity to push for the release of the former Marine, Amir Hekmati.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Amir Hekmati, a former Marine, has been held by Iran for more than two years.

item.title: Photo Archive Linked to Torture Seems Unlikely to Alter U.S. Policy on Syria
item.description: The Obama administration first learned last November about harrowing photographs that were said to document widespread torture in Syrian prisons, according to a senior official.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Ahmad al-Jarba, president of a Syrian opposition coalition, holds up an image said to be of a torture victim, in Switzerland.

item.title: Europe, Facing Economic Pain, May Ease Climate Rules
item.description: The European Union proposed to end binding national targets for renewable energy production, substituting a goal likely to be much harder to enforce.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Goats grazing near wind turbines in Fantanele and Cogealac villages, Romania.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Letter from China: A Race Against Time for a Second Child
item.description: Zhejiang Province has become the first to implement legal changes permitting many couples to have two children, after decades of only one. But elsewhere the wait is agonizing for many couples whose biological clock is ticking.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Although a relaxation in the one-child policy has been announced, laws have yet to be changed in many localities.

item.title: Syrian Peace Talks Open With Vitriol, as Official Rails at Rebels
item.description: The sense that the talks were headed for trouble was compounded when the proceedings ended without any hint of progress toward imposing local cease-fires or opening humanitarian corridors.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Protesters supporting President Bashar al-Assad of Syria demonstrated on Wednesday in Montreux, Switzerland, the site of the peace talks.

item.title: Unrest Deepens in Ukraine as Protests Turn Deadly
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovich met with opposition leaders after two protesters were shot to death and a civil uprising edged Kiev, the capital, toward a state of emergency.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: At least two people have died in the fighting between the riot police units, called by their Ukrainian name the Berkut, and protesters.

item.title: U.S. Offshore Wind Farm, Made in Europe
item.description: The promise of new jobs and work for American companies failed to come true, revealing shortcomings in the American offshore wind industry.
item.dc:creator: By DIANE CARDWELL
item.media:credit: Gretchen Ertl for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joel Gonzalez at Mass Tank in Middleborough, Mass. Mass Tank failed to gain work on a wind farm off Cape Cod.

item.title: Collections: A New World Around Every Corner
item.description: For a couple of dealers in antique maps, there is only one place that really counts.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID MASELLO
item.media:credit: Randy Harris for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph Gonzalez and Ralph Magnus’s Union Square apartment is filled with maps of Hispaniola and the West Indies. The living room’s treasures include a 1634 map by Willem Janszoon Blaeu (foreground, center left), one of only 10 in the world.

item.title: Paris Journal: At Resting Place for France’s ‘Great Men,’ Calls to Include More Women
item.description: Officials have been barraged with suggestions to add a woman to the greats buried in the Panthéon, where Marie Curie is the only woman interred on her own merit.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Agnes Dherbeys for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officials have been barraged with suggestions to add a woman to those buried in the Panthéon. Marie Curie is the only woman interred there on her own merit.

item.title: The Lede: Footage of Mayhem on the Streets of Kiev
item.description: Journalists who have been covering the standoff in Kiev for weeks uploaded dramatic images of the spiraling conflict to social networks from the streets on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Putin’s Olympic Fever Dream
item.description: Welcome to Sochi, a Soviet-style megaproject to make Joseph Stalin proud!
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:credit: Harf Zimmermann for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Olympic-flame monument, in front of Fisht Stadium.

item.title: Renowned Scholar In Egypt Charged With Espionage
item.description: Emad Shahin, a political scientist, was charged along with senior leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood with conspiring to undermine Egypt’s security.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Report Says China’s Elite Use Offshore Companies
item.description: Leaked documents show that thousands of wealthy, well-connected Chinese have set up companies in tax-haven countries to hold assets, an investigative reporting group says.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Goodyear Reaches Severance Deal With French Union
item.description: Workers at a Goodyear tire plant agreed to accept severance pay that they said was three times as much as the company had initially offered.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Union members burned tires at the Goodyear plant in Amiens, France, on Jan. 8.

item.title: Israeli Airstrike Kills 2 in Gaza
item.description: One of the dead was a member of the armed wing of Islamic Jihad, which vowed to retaliate for the Israeli attack.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and FARES AKRAM

item.title: The Lede: Video Shows Toronto’s Mayor Using Jamaican Patois in Obscene Rant About Police Surveillance
item.description: Two months after he claimed to have embraced sobriety, Mayor Rob Ford was caught on video Monday complaining about police surveillance of him and his associates in a drunken, obscenity-laced rant.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of a photograph posted on Instagram early Tuesday showing Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto at a fast-food restaurant.

item.title: Former Foxconn Managers Detained in a Bribery Case
item.description: Authorities are investigating whether several former managers accepted millions of dollars in bribes from partners of the electronics maker, which is a main supplier to Apple.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Foxconn factory in Chongqing, China. The company supplies the world’s electronics makers.

item.title: Chinese Activist’s Lawyers Call His Trial Unfair
item.description: The two lawyers defending Xu Zhiyong were silent in court on Wednesday, saying there was no point waging a legal fight against the prosecution.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Liu Chunxia, a supporter of Mr. Xu's, was detained on Wednesday by police officers near the court where he was being tried in Beijing.

item.title: The Lede: Ominous Text Message Sent to Protesters in Kiev Sends Chills Around the Internet
item.description: As the Orwellian text message sent to protesters in Ukraine on Tuesday chills the Internet, it seems worth asking if it is really that unusual.
item.dc:creator: By HEATHER MURPHY
item.media:credit: Andrew E. Kramer/The New York Times
item.media:description: A text message sent to the phones of people close to clashes in the Ukrainian capital, Kiev, on Tuesday read: "Dear subscriber, you are registered as a participant in a mass disturbance."

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 22
item.description: India celebrates its annual republic day on Jan. 26.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man running with the national flag in Agartala, Tripura. India celebrates its Republic Day on Jan. 26.

item.title: The Lede: War Crimes Experts Call Syrian Defector’s Photographs ‘Direct Evidence’ of Assad’s ‘Killing Machine’
item.description: A team of legal and forensic experts concluded that post-mortem photographs, provided to the Syrian opposition by a man who describes himself as a defector from President Bashar al-Assad’s security forces, offer “direct evidence” of torture and execution.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: In an Emergency, Call 100. Or is it 1098? Or 103?
item.description: In big Indian cities like Bangalore, the lack of a unified first-responder system and the inability to crack down on crank calls are endangering people who need help quickly.
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI
